questions.answerB: TMJ
questions.answerC: MRT
questions.answerD: AAP
questions.explanation: The main psychoactive substance in marijuana is called tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left footrest
questions.answerB: Near the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handle grip
questions.answerD: On the right handle grip
questions.explanation: The throttle of a motorcycle is usually located on the right handle grip. Be sure to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before riding.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Allow you to set up for turns.
questions.answerB: Allow an escape route.
questions.answerC: Allow you to avoid wind blasts from other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Allow you to be in another vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: If either tire goes flat while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Roll on the throttle.
questions.answerB: Hold the handle grips loosely.
questions.answerC: Gently apply the brake of the non-flat tire.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to exit the road more quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires goes flat while you are riding, you should ease off the throttle and maintain a straight course as you slow down. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat, if you are certain of which tire that is.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: When you are being passed by a vehicle on your left, you should:
questions.answerA: Help the other driver by moving as far to the right as possible.
questions.answerB: Help the other driver by moving to the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the left portion of your lane
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous because it may tempt them to merge back into your lane too soon. Stay in the center portion of the lane when being passed.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: When entering a turn, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Reduce their speed.
questions.answerC: Move their shoulders to match the angle of the turn.
questions.answerD: Sit up as high as possible.
questions.explanation: Before entering a turn, a motorcyclist should reduce their speed by closing the throttle and, if necessary, applying both brakes.

questions.question: Before every ride, it is important to check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The spokes.
questions.answerB: The tire tread.
questions.answerC: The lights.
questions.answerD: The seat fabric.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, you should complete a thorough check of your motorcycle. Be sure to check the rims and spokes to make sure none are bent, loose, or damaged; the condition and tread of the tires; and all of the lights.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, which portion of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerA: The left portion
questions.answerB: The center portion
questions.answerC: The right portion
questions.answerD: The shoulder
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of the lane to increase your line of sight and make yourself more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: The single most important thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.
questions.answerB: Wear shorts.
questions.answerC: Wear sneakers.
questions.answerD: Wear goggles.
questions.explanation: The single most effective action you can take to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.

questions.question: When riding, the best sitting position:
questions.answerA: Requires your arms be used to hold you up.
questions.answerB: Allows you to easily reach the controls.
questions.answerC: Keeps your arms straight when reaching the handle grips.
questions.answerD: Keeps your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be seated in a posture that allows you to use your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. You should not have to stretch to reach the handgrips and your arms should be slightly bent when holding them. You should keep your knees against the gas tank to maintain your balance.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerA: Two times
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: Riding with a passenger:
questions.answerA: Usually results in no difference in handling a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for beginning riders.
questions.answerC: Can affect the handling of a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Is encouraged to get operators used to different riding situations.
questions.explanation: A passenger puts extra weight on a motorcycle, which causes the motorcycle to handle differently. Only experienced riders should carry passengers.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger or cargo:
questions.answerA: It may take less time to accelerate, but more time to stop.
questions.answerB: It may take more time to accelerate and stop.
questions.answerC: It may take more time to accelerate, but less time to stop.
questions.answerD: It may take less time to accelerate and stop.
questions.explanation: Because of the additional weight added by cargo or a passenger, motorcycles may take longer to accelerate and stop than they would if only transporting the operator.

questions.question: If someone is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride faster to shake them.
questions.answerB: Alert the local police.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Allow them to pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to let them get in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Riding faster may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: It is difficult for other motorists to see motorcycles at night. To make up for that, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerA: Reduce their speed when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Sound their horn repeatedly when riding at night.
questions.answerC: Not ride at night.
questions.answerD: Stay directly in front of another vehicle to be seen in their headlights when riding at night.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safely riding at night include reducing your speed, increasing your following distance, using the lights of the car ahead to help see farther down the road, using your high beam headlight (unless following or meeting another vehicle), and being flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: When traveling in a group, riders should:
questions.answerA: Spread out to make the group easier to see.
questions.answerB: Stay close together to make the group easier to see.
questions.answerC: Separate occasionally.
questions.answerD: Ride in pairs.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, riders should maintain close ranks while also allowing adequate space cushions around each rider. Staying close together makes the group easier to see and reduces the risk that riders will become separated. Riders should not pair up because doing so does not allow adequate room for them to maneuver.

questions.question: Gloves can:
questions.answerA: Make it difficult to control a motorcycle and should be avoided.
questions.answerB: Help other drivers identify you.
questions.answerC: Provide an improved grip on the handlebars.
questions.answerD: Offer no protection.
questions.explanation: Gloves can provide you with an improved grip on your motorcycle's handlebars. They can also protect your hands in the event of a crash.

questions.question: Before riding, check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Your tires' inflation pressure.
questions.answerB: The amount of tread on your tires.
questions.answerC: The reflective quality of your tires.
questions.answerD: The general condition of the sidewalls on your tires.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, be sure to check your tires' inflation pressure, your tires' treadwear, and the general condition of the sidewalls and tread surface on the tires.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: Of the following, which should you not do to improve your safety when riding at night?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerC: Use your high beam headlight whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: To ride safely at night, you should reduce your speed, use your high beam headlight when you are not riding near other vehicles, and increase your following distance. Take advantage of vehicles ahead of you to provide clues about the upcoming road. Their headlights may help to illuminate the road ahead and their taillights will bounce up and down if the vehicle is being driven over bumps on the road.

questions.question: To get the best protection, be sure that your helmet:
questions.answerA: Meets Department of Transportation guidelines.
questions.answerB: Looks sturdy.
questions.answerC: Is inexpensive.
questions.answerD: Is in your favorite color.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: The best way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerC: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: If possible, change lanes and let a tailgater pass your vehicle. Speeding up may result in the driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed, thereby increasing the danger.

questions.question: A motorcycle is not as wide as a car:
questions.answerA: But still needs a full lane width to operate safely.
questions.answerB: And can share a lane with a car for short distances.
questions.answerC: And is required to share a lane with a car if traffic is congested.
questions.answerD: And can ride on the shoulder if the traffic lanes are crowded.
questions.explanation: Despite their small size, motorcycles still need a full lane width to operate safely. Lane sharing is generally prohibited.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerA: Lean as you lean.
questions.answerB: Hold onto the motorcycle seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: A passenger should lean with the operator through turns and curves. They should sit as far forward as possible, without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle, and hold onto passenger handholds or the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: Motorcycle headlights are:
questions.answerA: Usually more powerful than a car’s headlights.
questions.answerB: Usually just as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerC: Usually not as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerD: Usually larger than a car’s headlights.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle headlights are generally smaller and less powerful than those of cars.

questions.question: When you are being passed by another vehicle, which part of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerA: The left
questions.answerB: The center
questions.answerC: The right
questions.answerD: It doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with them. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous, as it could tempt the driver to re-enter your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If a driver is following you too closely, you should:
questions.answerA: Flash your brake light before you slow to warn the other driver.
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If someone is following you too closely, it is a good idea to flash your brake light before slowing down. A tailgater may be concentrating on you and not see upcoming hazards that require traffic to slow down.

questions.question: Impairment from alcohol:
questions.answerA: Begins with the first drink.
questions.answerB: Begins at about half of the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Occurs at the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Occurs only if you have had multiple drinks.
questions.explanation: As little as one drink can have a significant effect on the abilities that you need for safe riding. You can be impaired even if you are well below the legal blood alcohol limit. No amount of alcohol is safe to consume before riding.

questions.question: How can you discourage another vehicle from sharing your lane?
questions.answerA: Ride in the middle of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Swerve from side to side in your lane.
questions.explanation: To discourage automobile drivers from trying to share your lane, ride in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Before carrying a passenger in traffic for the first time, you should:
questions.answerA: Read books about carrying passengers.
questions.answerB: Practice riding on an empty road.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights so others can see you.
questions.answerD: Practice riding on the shoulder of a road.
questions.explanation: Before transporting a passenger or heavy load in traffic for the first time, practice riding on a quiet road to get used to how your motorcycle handles differently with the additional weight.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than you would normally.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you would normally.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerD: Not communicate with the passenger while riding.
questions.explanation: Because of a passenger's additional weight, a motorcycle will respond more slowly with a passenger on board than with just one occupant. With a passenger, you should travel a bit more slowly than you normally would, start slowing sooner than you normally would, and increase your following distance. Always warn your passenger of any special conditions ahead.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep riding, as the wobble will likely correct itself.
questions.answerB: Quickly brake.
questions.answerC: Close the throttle to slow down.
questions.answerD: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble will only increase the problem. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down while gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as you can, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Once off the road, you should address the problem causing the wobble.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Kick it away.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If a dog is chasing your motorcycle, downshift and slowly approach the dog. Once you have gotten close to the animal, accelerate and leave it behind. Do not attempt to kick it.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way for a rider to increase their visibility?
questions.answerA: Wearing proper clothing
questions.answerB: Using their headlight at all times
questions.answerC: Using their turn signals
questions.answerD: Waving at other drivers
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: Motorists entering a highway from an entrance ramp to your right may not see your motorcycle. To help the entering drivers, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerB: Flash your lights.
questions.answerC: Move to the left portion of your lane so they can share the lane, if necessary.
questions.answerD: Move into another lane, if necessary.
questions.explanation: Give plenty of room to vehicles merging onto a highway from an entrance ramp. Merge into a lane farther away from the entrance ramp, if necessary. If it is not possible to change lanes, adjust your speed to allow room for the vehicle to safely enter the highway.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a factor in determining blood alcohol content (BAC)?
questions.answerA: The amount of alcohol consumed
questions.answerB: How fast the alcohol is consumed
questions.answerC: The drinker's body weight
questions.answerD: How often the drinker consumes alcohol
questions.explanation: The three major factors that affect a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast the alcohol was consumed, and the drinker's body weight. It is illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, you should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate out of the wobble.
questions.answerB: Use the brakes immediately.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and gradually close the throttle.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: When approaching an object or uneven surface that you cannot avoid, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the motorcycle is leaning to one side.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Swerve quickly.
questions.answerD: Rise slightly off the seat to allow your legs to absorb the shock.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid riding over an obstacle or uneven surface, you should approach it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can, make sure that your motorcycle is upright, and rise slightly off your seat so your knees can absorb some of the force of impact. Just before contact, roll on the throttle slightly to lighten the front end.

questions.question: In general, riders should:
questions.answerA: Pick one lane position and always use it.
questions.answerB: Change lane positions frequently to prevent monotony.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position that maximizes their space cushion.
questions.answerD: Never use the center lane position.
questions.explanation: Because road and traffic conditions are always changing, the safest lane position is also always changing. Choose the position that will maximize your space cushion and allow other drivers to see you most easily.

questions.question: Which of the following does not need to be checked regularly?
questions.answerA: The brakes
questions.answerB: The fasteners
questions.answerC: The tires
questions.answerD: The paint
questions.explanation: Before every ride, you should check your motorcycle's tires, controls, chains, sprockets, shock absorbers, fasteners, and brakes. A small mechanical issue on a motorcycle can be extremely dangerous in traffic.

questions.question: The front brake can provide how much of a motorcycle's braking power?
questions.answerA: 10 percent
questions.answerB: 25 percent
questions.answerC: 50 percent
questions.answerD: 75 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide at least three-quarters of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: It is recommended that a motorcyclist:
questions.answerA: Shift gears in a turn.
questions.answerB: Shift gears before a turn.
questions.answerC: Change power suddenly in a turn.
questions.answerD: Ride the brake throughout the turn.
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you change gears prior to entering a turn.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerB: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Means that the other driver knows you are there.
questions.explanation: You should never take eye contact with another driver as a guarantee that they will properly yield the right-of-way to you.

questions.question: If a friend has had too much to drink and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Let them.
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take roads that are not crowded.
questions.answerC: Not get involved.
questions.answerD: Take their keys.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding, including taking their keys, if necessary. Arrange an alternative way for them to get home.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Serve little purpose since motorcycles are smaller than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are very important to alert other motorists to a rider's intentions.
questions.answerC: Should not be used if no vehicles are close to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are more complicated than those on a car.
questions.explanation: You are especially vulnerable as a motorcyclist, so it is very important to use your turn signals to alert others to your intentions. Always use them any time that you plan to change lanes or turn, even if you don't think anyone else is nearby.

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered protective clothing for a motorcyclist?
questions.answerA: A jacket
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: A stocking cap
questions.explanation: You should wear appropriate protective clothing when riding. Protective garments include sturdy pants and jackets that entirely cover your arms and legs, boots or heavy shoes that cover and support your ankles, and sturdy gloves.

questions.question: A potential danger of braking too hard is:
questions.answerA: Losing traction on one or both wheels.
questions.answerB: Coming to a complete stop before you expect to.
questions.answerC: Popping a tire.
questions.answerD: Taking too long to stop.
questions.explanation: If you over-apply your brakes, you may lose traction on one or both wheels and crash.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerB: Ride faster.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Kick it away.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, motorcycle riders should turn their heads to look over their shoulders because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They can catch the attention of other drivers by turning their heads.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are not really helpful.
questions.answerD: They should try to make eye contact with surrounding drivers.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, a motorcycle has blind spots that cannot be seen by a rider using their mirrors. A motorcyclist should always turn their head to check for vehicles or other hazards in their blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: Of the following, the colors that best allow riders to be seen are:
questions.answerA: Orange and red.
questions.answerB: Green and blue.
questions.answerC: Purple and gold.
questions.answerD: Black and white.
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to others, wearing clothing that is bright orange, red, yellow, or green is best.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Not be worn.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Brightly-colored and/or reflective clothing will increase your chances of being seen under any conditions. Remember that most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight so it is still best to wear bright clothing during the day.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerA: 0.02 percent
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.answerD: 0.1 percent
questions.explanation: In the state of Kentucky, a person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When turning left, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the right handgrip.
questions.answerB: Press the left handgrip.
questions.answerC: Press both handgrips at the same time.
questions.answerD: Not press either handgrip.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle must lean to make a turn. To make it lean in the appropriate direction, press the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: Where is the clutch lever usually located?
questions.answerA: On the left handgrip
questions.answerB: On the right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The clutch lever of a motorcycle is usually located on the left handgrip.

questions.question: To effectively provide protection for a motorcycle rider, pants should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Be made of a heavy material.
questions.answerC: Fit loosely enough that they flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Be short and expose some parts of the legs.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear pants that cover your entire legs and are made of leather or another sturdy synthetic material. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but not so snugly that it restricts your movement.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Help you avoid road hazards.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid being seen by other drivers.
questions.answerD: Increase your ability to be seen by others.
questions.explanation: A well-chosen lane position should increase your ability to see and be seen and keep you out of other drivers' blind spots. It should help you avoid surface hazards, protect your lane from other drivers, communicate your intentions to others, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and offer you an escape route from any hazards that may arise.

questions.question: To qualify as a moped, a motorcycle must:
questions.answerA: Weigh less than 75 pounds.
questions.answerB: Have a seat that is less than 15 inches off the ground.
questions.answerC: Produce no more than five brake horsepower.
questions.answerD: Not have a seat.
questions.explanation: In Connecticut, a motor-driven cycle (also known as a moped) is legally defined as any motorcycle, motor scooter, or bicycle with an attached motor that produces no more than five brake horsepower and seat that is at least 26 inches from the ground.

questions.question: Which of the following is not important when looking for a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: The helmet meets U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: The helmet fits snugly all the way around your head.
questions.answerC: The helmet has no obvious defects, such as cracks or loose padding.
questions.answerD: The helmet looks cool.
questions.explanation: To ensure that a helmet will provide you with as much protection as possible, check to see if it meets U.S. DOT and state standards; fits snugly all the way around your head; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: To control your motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit with your arms propping you up rather than steering.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank for balance.
questions.answerC: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerD: Sit so far back that you must stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: When riding, keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance in turns. Sit so that you can use your arms to steer rather than to prop yourself up. Sit far enough forward that your arms are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips, and keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Each traffic lane gives the motorcyclist how many paths of travel?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: Each traffic lane provides three paths of travel for motorcyclists: the left, center, and right portions of the lane.

questions.question: When going through a turn on a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your eyes focused close to the front of the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Look through the turn to where you want to go.
questions.answerC: Turn your entire body to see through the turn.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed before the turn.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When you ride a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: If you are riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in a lane position that makes you visible to the driver.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about your placement.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding directly behind a car, it is usually safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. If you are riding in the center of the lane, you are most likely to be visible in the rearview mirror of the vehicle ahead. Most drivers check their rearview mirror more frequently than they check their side mirrors.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Make sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Move to the edge of the road.
questions.answerD: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safe riding on slippery surfaces include reducing your speed, avoiding sudden moves, staying away from the edge of the road, and riding in the tire tracks left by other cars.

questions.question: When being passed, you should not move to the portion of the lane farthest from the passing driver because it:
questions.answerA: Discourages the passing driver from cutting into your lane too early.
questions.answerB: Encourages the passing driver to cut into your lane too early.
questions.answerC: Encourages the passing driver to complete the pass as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Encourages other drivers to pass you.
questions.explanation: Moving into the portion of your lane farthest from a passing vehicle is potentially dangerous because it could encourage the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so. It is safest to stay in the center of a lane when being passed.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping the size of a group of riders small is:
questions.answerA: A small group is less easily separated in traffic than a larger group.
questions.answerB: A small group can disregard traffic laws to stay together.
questions.answerC: Riders will always be trying to catch up to the group.
questions.answerD: It will be difficult to keep track of where everyone is.
questions.explanation: There are several advantages to keeping groups of riders small. In comparison to a large group, a small group is easier for other vehicles to pass safely, is less likely to get separated by traffic or stop lights, and creates less need for slower riders to hurry to catch up to the rest of the group.

questions.question: Goggles will:
questions.answerA: Protect only your eyes.
questions.answerB: Be an equally as effective as a face shield.
questions.answerC: Offer the same protection as a windshield.
questions.answerD: Provide protection for your entire face.
questions.explanation: Wearing goggles provides protection for your eyes, but not for the rest of your face. A face shield provides protection for your whole face and is recommended above goggles. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerB: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: A motorcyclist can discourage other vehicles from lane sharing by:
questions.answerA: Riding in the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Riding in the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Giving dirty looks if another driver moves into their lane.
questions.answerD: Riding in a zigzag pattern to fill up a lane.
questions.explanation: Any time a driver may be tempted to try to squeeze into your lane next to you, ride in the center portion of the lane to discourage them from doing so.

questions.question: Making eye contact with other drivers:
questions.answerA: Is the best way to know that they see you.
questions.answerB: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will yield to you when they should.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never take eye contact as a guarantee that a driver will properly yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to register that they are there.

questions.question: When entering a highway while riding in a group, riders should:
questions.answerA: Enter in a single-file formation.
questions.answerB: Enter in a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: Enter in pairs.
questions.answerD: Stop and wait for a completely clear opening in traffic to allow all riders to enter at once.
questions.explanation: While it is generally best for groups to ride in a staggered formation, riders should shift into a single-file formation when going through a curve, making a turn, entering a highway, or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Face shields and goggles:
questions.answerA: Will likely never need to be replaced.
questions.answerB: Will develop scratches and become brittle, requiring regular replacement.
questions.answerC: Should be made of breakable materials so they can break away in the event of a crash.
questions.answerD: Should not allow air to pass through.
questions.explanation: Face shields and goggles, being made of plastic, will develop scratches and become brittle as they age. Replace them regularly to ensure maximum protection and comfort.

questions.question: In a normal turn:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle and rider should lean together.
questions.answerB: The motorcycle and rider should lean in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: The motorcycle should lean, but the rider should not.
questions.answerD: The rider should lean, but the motorcycle should not.
questions.explanation: During normal turns, the motorcycle and the rider should be leaning together at the same angle. In slow, tight turns, only the motorcycle should lean while the rider keeps their body straight up.

questions.question: The only way to rid your body of alcohol is through:
questions.answerA: Time.
questions.answerB: Drinking coffee.
questions.answerC: Exercising.
questions.answerD: Taking a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the alcoholic content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it. There are no shortcuts to sobering up.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while you are riding and you must stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat while you are riding, hold the handgrips firmly, ease off the throttle, and maintain a straight course. If you need to brake, gradually apply the brake to the tire that is not flat. As you slow down, edge to the side of the road, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: If the chain or belt of your motorcycle breaks, you will:
questions.answerA: Experience a sudden increase in power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerB: Experience a sudden loss of power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerC: Experience a sudden loss of power to the front wheel.
questions.answerD: Experience a sudden increase in power to the front wheel.
questions.explanation: If your drive chain or belt fails, you will experience an immediate loss of power to the rear wheel.

questions.question: If you are preparing to pass another operator on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Get into the right part of the lane so you can be seen in their side mirror.
questions.answerB: Get into the left part of the lane to increase your line of sight.
questions.answerC: Stay in the center part of the lane so you can be seen in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Weave in your lane to draw attention to yourself.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, ride in the left portion of your lane to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to any drivers in the passing lane. Use your mirrors and turn your head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: When following a car, usually the best portion of the lane to ride in is:
questions.answerA: The left portion.
questions.answerB: The center portion.
questions.answerC: The right portion.
questions.answerD: The left or right portions.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: Rain suits:
questions.answerA: Should not be used.
questions.answerB: Should not balloon when riding.
questions.answerC: Are not needed since motorcycles shouldn't be operated in the rain.
questions.answerD: Should tear easily.
questions.explanation: High-quality rain suits designed for motorcycle riding will resist tearing and ballooning when a rider travels at high speeds.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield should be all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Resistant to penetration.
questions.answerC: Able to fasten securely.
questions.answerD: Airtight.
questions.explanation: To be effective, eye protection and face shields must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; give a clear view to either side; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumed eight alcoholic drinks four hours ago, how many drinks likely remain in their body?
questions.answerA: One drink
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks left in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since the last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. In this case, the alcohol content of about four drinks would remain.

questions.question: Use a turn signal:
questions.answerA: When you’re planning to increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Only when there is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerC: Any time you plan on changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: You should use a turn signal every time you plan to turn or change lanes, even if you think no one else is around to see it.

questions.question: If attempting to brake in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake more gradually than you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you are not in the curve to brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Because tires have less traction when a motorcycle is leaning than when it is upright, always try to position your motorcycle in an upright position before braking. If you must brake while in a curve, apply the brakes more smoothly and gradually than if your motorcycle was traveling on a straightaway.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as effectively as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects your entire face in a crash. Goggles protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: When crossing angled railroad tracks, it is usually safest to approach the tracks:
questions.answerA: By proceeding straight within your lane.
questions.answerB: At a 45-degree angle.
questions.answerC: At a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerD: At a fast speed.
questions.explanation: In general, it is safest to simply proceed straight in your lane when crossing angled railroad tracks. Turning to approach tracks at a right angle can be dangerous because it may send you traveling into another lane.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Avoid other road users' blind spots.
questions.answerB: Provide a good view of the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Provide a poor view of road hazards.
questions.answerD: Invite others to share your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should help you to see others and be seen by them. Avoid riding in another driver's blind spot for a long period of time.

questions.question: You can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerA: Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Not using your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Wearing dark clothing.
questions.answerD: Waving at people.
questions.explanation: To increase your visibility, you can wear clothing that is brightly-colored or that contains reflective materials. Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle, using your turn signals, and flashing your brake light when appropriate are also good ways to get the attention of other road users.

questions.question: A motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Cannot tip over.
questions.answerB: Can tip over if making a turn too fast.
questions.answerC: Is designed to take corners at any speed.
questions.answerD: Should not be used for loading items.
questions.explanation: Even with three wheels on the ground, a sidecar can tip over if it is being turned too sharply or is moving too fast for a corner.

questions.question: When approaching an uneven surface, such as a bump or pothole, you should rise slightly off of your seat:
questions.answerA: So you can jump off the motorcycle if you need to.
questions.answerB: So your legs can absorb the shock.
questions.answerC: So other drivers can see you better.
questions.answerD: So you can get a better view of the uneven surface.
questions.explanation: When riding over an uneven surface, rising off of your seat will allow your joints to absorb some of the force of impact. This will make it less likely that the impact of the surface will throw you off of the motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, a jacket should be worn:
questions.answerA: No matter the weather conditions.
questions.answerB: Only on cool days.
questions.answerC: Only on warm days.
questions.answerD: Only if the ride will be longer than half an hour.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should always wear a long-sleeved jacket when riding, even in warm weather when you may not think you need a jacket. It can help protect you against the sun and dehydration in hot weather.

questions.question: To reduce the amount of time you need to react to a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: In potential high-risk areas, such as school zones or construction zones, cover the clutch and both brakes. This cuts down the amount of time you will need to react to a hazard.

questions.question: In New Hampshire, a person who is age 21 or older with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerA: 0.02 percent
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is of legal drinking age with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and unsafe to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: One way to tell if your rear tire has gone flat while riding is if:
questions.answerA: There is a hissing noise coming from the rear of the bike.
questions.answerB: The back end is jerking from side to side.
questions.answerC: You are unable to accelerate.
questions.answerD: The rear brake does not work.
questions.explanation: If your rear tire fails, the back of your motorcycle will likely jerk from side to side. It is rare for motorcyclists to actually hear a tire fail.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.answerB: Tighten your hold on the handle grips and increase your speed to get past the hazard.
questions.answerC: Travel in a zigzag motion.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder instead of on the grooves.
questions.explanation: The weaving motion that occurs when a motorcycle rides over rain grooves or bridge gratings is generally not dangerous. If you experience weaving when riding over one of these surfaces, simply relax and proceed straight across the grooves or gratings at a steady speed. Trying to compensate for the weaving motion by zigzagging is more dangerous than riding straight.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is slippery.
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerD: Use your high beam light, if possible.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. Use your high beam headlight, except when following or meeting another vehicle.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: Always look through a turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head to look, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: What should a motorcyclist do to prevent possible injury when riding on a slippery surface?
questions.answerA: Increase their speed.
questions.answerB: Reduce their speed.
questions.answerC: Make sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When riding on a slippery surface, it is safest to decrease your speed. Making sudden moves on a slippery surface could cause your motorcycle to skid. Do not travel on the shoulder to escape a slippery road.

questions.question: If only one alcoholic drink is consumed:
questions.answerA: Judgment and riding abilities can still be affected.
questions.answerB: There is usually no effect on the body.
questions.answerC: There is an effect on the body, but it only lasts for a short time.
questions.answerD: There is an effect on the body, but it can be eliminated by drinking coffee.
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can significantly affect the skills that are needed for safe riding. The only way to remove the alcohol content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerA: On short trips.
questions.answerB: On long trips.
questions.answerC: After at least an hour of riding.
questions.answerD: After more than 8 hours of riding.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on trips shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: A helmet should not:
questions.answerA: Meet U.S. DOT standards.
questions.answerB: Fit snugly.
questions.answerC: Be without obvious defects.
questions.answerD: Have been previously worn in an accident.
questions.explanation: You will get the greatest amount of protection from a helmet if it meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards, fits snugly all the way around, and has no obvious defects. A helmet worn at the time of a crash should be replaced.

questions.question: When should your rearview mirror be adjusted?
questions.answerA: After starting the motorcycle
questions.answerB: Before starting the motorcycle
questions.answerC: During the ride
questions.answerD: At a traffic signal
questions.explanation: You should clean and adjust both mirrors before starting your motorcycle. Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you.
